entry.used_skills: This isn't a DBT skill, but I did take time to step back from my own hyper-focus - which is an ADHD thing where I get fixated on one specific thing, and can't get away from it - I took time to step away from my code project and breathe and ground, and get a new perspective on the work, and come back to it with fresh eyes.
entry.homework:
This week's homework is the "how" skill of describing. I think I'm doing okay; at least once a day in the past few days, I've had a moment where I was ruminating or feeling anxious, or stuck in a certain feeling, where I was able to step back and describe to myself what's going on. 

I was able to just say, "Oh, I'm thinking about this thing right now"/"I'm worried about this thing." 

Since one of the things I was fixated on was my health - which feels like a catastrophe at the moment - it was helpful to go from the thought/feeling, "Something is deeply wrong with my body," to, "I *feel* like something is deeply wrong with my body. 

It might not seem like a huge difference, but it did help. I was able to validate the thought without giving it as much weight as I had before. Which was useful!
entry.gratitude: I'm grateful for my partner, who encourages me and helps me find a more balanced perspective when I get too hyper-fixated on a project at hand. I'm also grateful for the food I ate, and the ability to play piano and code.

entry.notes:
It was a calm day in my head. My thoughts didn't go "off the rails," and I didn't find myself fighting to keep from panicking every other moment. 

Last night I lost my phone, and so I wasn't able to read on it before bed, or this morning. I wonder if that made a difference. 

I probably got more sleep that I would have, if I'd had my phone. 

Note to self: *cut browsing on phone out of nighttime routine*

time: 13:00

EM 5: Anxiety was really high during group (10am - noon) because there were men in group this week. It made my anxiety shoot through the roof, so I distracted with hyperfocus on notes. 

The good thing is that I noticed and identified that it was anxiety/panic, and that it was too high to try to bring it down in the moment. And that I distracted instead. I would like to have a better way to self-soothe in future moments, though. 

I also keep having thoughts that are disturbing and that I can't seem to go away. Susan says that pushing thoughts away makes them more active, but I don't really know what the alternative is. 

PM 2: I have the usual pain in my neck and shoulders; hopefully it won't get any worse than that today. 

Joy 2: I'm tired, so not feeling super joyful, but I do feel focused and productive, so if I get some work done with Elle today I'll probably feel better. I'm also stressed out about the minutia of dealing with meds refills, and all the money that OTC meds cost, so that ups my stress levels and makes it hard. to stay in the moment, which is where I can find joy.

entry.homework:
Today in group we talked about the "how" skills of mindfulness, and specifically being mindful "Nonjudgementally, Effectively, and One-Mindedly." 

Week: 2, Skill: How/NonJudgement

Today I started using my skill of just saying, "Okay," to the thoughts and emotions that come into my. head ("How skills of non-judgement.") That skill is about not judging thoughts as good or bad, and also not pushing away the thoughts you perceive as bad; instead, just noticing them.

So I did something I learned in DBT the last time around, and just started saying, "Okay" to my thoughts. 

For example, thinking "I'm mad at [X thing]," and then just responding back to that thought, in a neutral "tone" - just the simple word "Okay."

It's like saying, "Okay, that's a thought or emotion that you have, and that's fine! It is a thought/emotion. That's what it is." 

I did feel better and more grounded afterwards, so I do think it helped. I'm going to reincorporate that one back into my mental routine.
entry.other:
I had a lot of energy today, and my thoughts were generally focused and clear. I didn't have to fight to keep my mind from going off the rails like a train off the track, so that was nice. 

Some days are like that, and some days are the opposite. I don't really know yet what makes the difference, but I'd like to find out.
entry.gratitude: I'm grateful for the trip to Powell's Books that I got to take, and for the joy of new notebooks and pens, and for the ability to be outside on a pleasantly warm summer day with blue skies! I'm also grateful for my partner Kent.

entry.notes:
Time: 2:20 PM

Calm: 4/5 I'm taking the morning to not work, and to just journal and read tarot and also read a DBT book from the library. Whenever I shut the door in my own room, and sit in my "book nook" and journal or make art, I feel calm and peaceful. 

Joy: 4/5 Journaling, reading, and resting bring me quiet joy

Racing Thoughts: 3/5 My thoughts are going a million miles a minute this morning, but I found things to focus on (DBT book, tarot draw, journaling) and that's really helped. 

As Scott and I always say, If you recognize the "brain weasels" (racing thoughts) and give them something to chew on, they'll leave you in peace :) 

Intentionality: 3/5 This season of my life is about stopping to REST before my brain and body just give out on me. In the last year alone I've had several mental health crisis, and one full on breakdown. It's definitely time to step back, rest, and reflect on what's been going right and wrong, so I can more mindfully choose the path ahead. 

Phys. mis: 3/5 Tightness between shoulder blades, neck and shouder/back pain, need to find a better way to sit

Emo mis: 1/5 Lots of racing thoughts, but for the moment they're at bay. Mindfulness helps

Skills score: 5/5 I've been using lots of them today! Taking time aside to breathe and journal and read has made all the difference.

Fatigue: 4/10

I'm tired and fatigued today - I didn't get to sleep until 4 am (wasn't sleepy. I ate dinner late, though.)

Morning mindfulness: I decided to do a tarot draw and journal for my morning mindfulness, which I'm defining as, "Choose a single activity and focus only on that for at least 20 minutes. Single minded, even if there are multiple sensory inputs." 

I journaled about the cards "Temperance," and the "Knight of Wands." 

Tarot Card: The Knight of Wands represents being passionate but potentially reckless, and charging ahead toward your goals. It's a necessary energy - you wouldn't get anywhere without passion and motivation - but it can also be destructive, if not tempered.

Tarot Card: Temperance. Temperance represents what I'm working toward in DBT: a self that is more present, mindful, and grounded. A self that takes time to pause and reflect on the moment before acting. A self who is wise and balanced between emotion and reason. 

To me, Temperance also represents intentionality. Whereas the Knight is focused on the immediate future and the immediate desire or goal, I think Temperance takes a longer look at things, and prioritizes tasks as a whole before diving into any one particular thing. 

The strength of the Knight is that they are immediate, and present, and fully immersed in what they are doing. Without that, Temperance would be lost in the land of map-making. But without Temperance's planning and vision, the Knight might unknowingly charge right off a cliff, with the best of intentions. 

So, I think the Knight & Temperance have the potential to balance each other out really beautifully! 

I'm going to use that as a metaphor/theme for the next season of life, I think. It feels relevant to the ideas of Emotion, Logic, and Wise Mind that DBT talks about! 

Note to self: Research the Temperance card more, and compare the artwork in different decks. Create an altar space to her.

8 PM

Em mis 1/5: I was hyper focused on rest this morning, and then hyper focused on work this evening, so I was in a pleasant flow and didn't have time to be very distressed. Did have anxiety and racing thoughts, though.

I also didn't have any negative interactions with K, which helps. I'm afraid that I will again soon, but for today it's okay. 

Phys mis: 3/5, the usual

Joy 4: I got to be creative (reading and journaling) and be in the flow (code projects I like, including this one.) Which was great! 

[Intentionality 4: I'm really proud of this one! Instead of just responding to stimulus today, and going wherever my wandering focus took me, I decided what projects I was going to work on, and how I was going to spend my time, and I did! It was lovely.

That's a goal I want to focus on: choosing where my attention goes during the day as far as what projects I dedicate time to.]

entry.homework:
Today I've been working on stepping back from my thoughts instead of engaging with them. Normally, when I have a thought that I consider "negative," I deal with it by trying to reason with it, or trying to change it into something more "positive." And that gets really, really exhausting. 

This week we're working on mindfulness without judgement, and also observing and describing thoughts from a distance, without clinging on to them. 

So today I'm stepping back and letting my thoughts be what they are, instead of trying to argue with them. And that's been really freeing - and also a lot less exhausting than the other way to do things. 

For example, there are several things about my current situation in life (health, residence) that frankly suck right now. And normally, when I have a negative thought about one of those things, I immediately respond with a list of reasons of why I should be more grateful. Or I try to provide "positive" counter arguments. 

But today I'm just letting the thoughts be what they are. If I'm upset or complaining about something in my head I just...let myself complain. If I have a thought that I don't like something about my situation, I just let that thought be, instead of trying to reason with it, or "talk myself out of" thinking or feeling that way. 

It's going well so far!
entry.other:
Tarot: I did a tarot reading this morning, about today, the immediate future (tomorrow) and the long-term future. 

Past: 2 of Cups
Today: Hanged Man (forbearance through pain)
Tomorrow: Knight of Wands (impulsivity, passion, charging ahead in a new or creative direction)
Long term future: Temperance (Balance between reason and passion, long-term planning and stability, *creating calm and fulfillment in the midst of stress.*)
entry.gratitude: tarot cards, music, the ability to write, the blue sky, the green leaves on trees outside my window, colorful little paper stars

entry.notes: It's been a long day/week. I'm exhausted and still not sleeping well, and I don't even know why. I'm just so dang tired and wired at the same time. My heart feels like an adrenaline rush and I just. Don't know what to do.

EM 1/5: Been mostly hyperfocused, so not thinking about painful things. Brain was racing all night last night, though. Couldn't get to sleep until like 4:30

PM 1/5: Stomach's not feeling great. Not as bad as it could be, though

Joy/Gratitude/Calm - I'm mostly just exhausted

Intentionality 4/5 - I've done a good job of focusing on my tasks for the day and getting done what I needed to

7 AM

Woke up at 3:30 AM, couldn't get back to sleep. My thoughts have been racing for what feels like days, and I can't get my brain to calm down and rest/sleep.

Been a hard day. Feeling really lonely at home. Tired and a heavy heart. Feeling like I don't have a direction or purpose, and I don't know what to do with myself and my time. Just...not really sure what my priorities and goals are right now, and that's hard.
entry.focus_phrase: You have to learn to love what's good for you.

Joy is low bc of loneliness

Emotional misery 4/5 - Same as above. Exhausted, lonely, and my thoughts won't stop spinning around everything I don't like in the relationship I'm in. I honestly don't know if there's an abnormal amount wrong with the relationship, or if my thoughts are just chewing my life to death. 

It's sort of horrifying to experience though. I feel sick often. Physically nauseous and ill. 

Other numbers (gratitude, calm, intentionality) are all low for the reason above. Racing thoughts, incessant worry, and a brain that won't seem to stop.

entry.used_skills: Describing my thoughts, which helps me distance from them. Trying to understand that what *feels* true isn't necessarily what *is* true. Feelings are valid, but are not objective fact, and just because I feel like something is true, doesn't mean that it is.
entry.homework: I did the "Interpersonal Effectiveness myths" worksheet
entry.other: Went to bed before midnight, but woke up at 3:30, hungry and unable to go back to sleep.

He'll go with me when I ask him too, and he said he'd come with me to get my foot fixed as well. I appreciate that he's making an effort to "get out of his comfort zone" for me.

entry.notes:
9 PM

SI & self harm urge: Just feeling tired and like things are pointless right now. Not sure what my purpose or focus is, and that's just really hard. Feeling incredibly lonely and unloved by my partner as well. 

Emotional misery 5/5: See above. Feeling rejected and deeply lonely at home. 

Gratitude 3/5: I got to see my sister and niece tonight, and that was really nice! 

Racing thoughts 4/5: My thoughts just keep spinning and spinning about Kent. I feel like I can't tell up from down with him, and I never know if I'm going to get manic Kent or depressed Kent, and all of it is just. Really hard to deal with. It makes me feel like I'm crazy and unstable myself, even though I know I'm not. 

Skills score 2/5: I did remember to practice mindfulness today, while driving, and to be in the moment and use all of my senses. I have also been practicing describing my thoughts and feelings, to help ground myself in reality, and in the fact that feelings and thoughts aren't necessarily objective reality.

7:30 AM 

I went to bed on time but woke up at 3:30 AM. Yesterday was really hard and my brain was all over the place, but It's now after 7 and I've been working since I woke up, and I feel SO much better than I have in quite awhile. I'm just listening to music and working on my DBT program, and I just feel calm and focused for the first time in like a week. 

I also had two rolls with jam, and water. 

Note: The numbers above look low, but they're real numbers; I just entered them. Things are just wonderfully calm rn, for once.

Overall: feeling okay and tentatively hopeful so far. I just want to keep my mind on track and not veering off the tracks again like it has often for the past few weeks. I just want to find some peace and sanity in my head.

entry.used_skills:
Intentionality was a big focus for me today. I read a definition of mindfulness as "attending to the present moment, with intent," and I like that. One way I'm interpreting it in my life right now is by trying to take time in the morning to think about my day, and maybe draw tarot cards or read an inspiring quote. 

Then I try to set a focus or theme for the day - something I can focus on and use as a narrative to make sense of what I'm experiencing. Finding meaning through spirituality is definitely helpful, and I think mindfulness is going to really help with that!

entry.notes:
Huh. I just spent the first hour or so of my day doing tarot journal, interspersed with some conversation with friends, and some code. Now, afterwards, I feel really calm. 

All my negative numbers (misery, racing thoughts, etc) are down, and my positive numbers (joy, gratitude, calm, intentionality) are way higher than normal! My "calm" number has never been 5, that I can remember. It's rare. 

So, huh. Journaling and getting grounded in the format really does help!
entry.skills_focus: Coming to grips with reality as it is

entry.used_skills: I feel like I've been intentional today, and I've been grounded and focused. I think doing tarot journaling this morning really helped. It got me centered and ready to sort of accept the day - and my situation - for what it is, instead of trying to make it something that it isn't. And that really helped.
entry.homework: Already done. I rewrote all the "assumptions" on the worksheet.

entry.notes: I feel like I've been intentional today, and I've been grounded and focused. I think doing tarot journaling this morning really helped. Other than that though, my thoughts were surprisingly non-racing-y. I had to deal with a lot at the doctor's office, but I actually stayed pretty calm, and sensory things like lights and noise didn't bother me like they usually do.

I'm not sure what made the difference, but it was definitely noticable.

entry.notes:
7:40 AM

Went to bed early last night and got up early today. Hours of sleep: 7+. 

Phys mis 3/5: Pain in neck and shoulders, ongoing, but it's been worse for the past few days. I think I'm not getting good quality sleep because of it. 

Em mis: 4/5 I'm not sure why I put that number, but it feels right. I've had a long couple weeks with a lot of trauma dug up and left to rot in the sun, and it's been exhausting. I think I need to find a way to rest and decompress my body, after everything it's going through. 

Gratitude: 4/5 At the same time, my gratitude is also high. I've been reconnecting with old friends, and that's been really good! Trying to get back to work, too. I need a schedule and more of a purpose again.

entry.used_skills:
Yesterday I used the 4/7/8 breathing skill while I was at the doctor's, and it really helped! I was seeing a male doctor I'd never seen before, and I would normally be a *lot* more nervous than I was. 

I had to sit and wait for the doctor to come in, so in the meantime I just did my breathing, and it helped. I was able to get through the entire appointment without panic. Which is huge for me. 

Today I plan to use: 4/7/8 breathing skill, and the mindfulness skills of observing and describing without judgement
entry.other: I also took an anti-antacid this morning (the "Acid Controller" stuff Elle recommended from Walgreens) and that may be making a difference in anxiety levels as well.

entry.used_skills: I used the skill of "describing." I'm still really worried about my health, but I was able to step back and say, "I FEEL like my health is terrible," instead of well, being stuck in the cycle of that feeling. It doesn't change the fact that I'm dealing with genuinely scary symptoms right now (such as, ya know, the right side of my body losing significant amounts of sensation) but it did help me at least name what was going on. Which made the thoughts easier to bear.
entry.homework:
I'm struggling with the homework since I feel like I don't have enough information to go off of, so I found a DBT Workbook at Barnes and Noble and picked it up. It's specific to anxiety, so I think that will be good. 

I also got a book on Buddhist mindfulness by Pema Chodron, so I'm going to start reading those two side by side as I go through the DBT curriculum, to hopefully help me understand more and fill in the gaps.
entry.other:
I'm feeling really lost in the interpersonal effectiveness module right now, and a lot of it is frankly triggering. I'm also having a hard time not panicking during group, since there are men there. It's hard to push through. 

In medical news, I'm getting more tests run tomorrow, and I'm both anxious and hopeful. I'm anxious bc I feel in my bones right now that something is very wrong. And I'm worried that whatever it is needs to be diagnosed soon so I can keep it from getting worse. I'm glad I finally found a doctor who seems willing to listen when I speak, and seems willing to test me for things. 

I'm going to follow up with that doc and try to find out what's going wrong. 

Prayer: may the tests tomorrow be illuminating, and lead me to the answers I seek.

9 PM

Had a good day! Got up early and had some energy; I ate well and took meds at regular intervals, and used my inhaler.

MEDS CHANGE: I started Singulair today. It can have bad side effects on people with mental health issues, but two doctors now have told me it's safe to try, so I'm giving it a go. So far so good - I don't think I've had any major effects today, aside from some stomach problems this morning, but that could be from something else. 

I'm hopeful that it will improve both my breathing and my immune symptoms; it sounds like it might! 

I found a book on DBT (Finally!) and also a book on Buddhist mindfulness that looks really good. Gonna dive into those this week.

5:30 PM

Trying to rest today. I did too much yesterday physically and am out of "walking" spoons today. So I'm trying not to stress and taking it easy by resting and drawing/watching tv.

All the scores feel pretty middle of the road/neutral atm, and that's why.

Intentionality: 4/5 because I'm focusing intentionally on rest, and I'm doing a good job keeping myself fed, cared for, and calm. 

Skills score - I'm doing breathing exercises and also trying not to "catastrophize" my thoughts.

Specifically, the idea of stepping back from "planning" a conversation, and just freeing yourself to imagine what you truly want to communicate, and what you value in the interaction, was useful. I'd never thought about it like that before.
entry.gratitude: I'm thankful for the chance to move ahead; I'm thankful for the DBT program and for Henry; I'm grateful for all the people in my life and the ongoing chance to reconnect with them and reform bridges even after time has passed. It's not sunny; that does affect my mood.

Emotional mis 4/5: Score is high because I'm finally becoming more aware of my emotions, instead of always shoving them away. Starting to read the book, "Welcoming the Unwelcome" by Pema Chödrön has been helpful in that regard. So has "Building a Life Worth Living" by Marsha Linehan.
entry.focus_phrase: Build a life worth living. The power to do so is in your hands.

entry.notes:
(recorded morning after)

Didn't take Concerta but did take other meds as scheduled and drank coffee. I went two nights with poor sleep before this, so was pretty out of it. Still managed to stay focused and get tasks done though, including a big chunk of code learning. That was good.

I've also moved my keyboard downstairs and now I can play it when I want, and that's been really good. It's helped a lot with levels of joy. 

I want to start writing songs too!

entry.skills: Active listening and assuming positive intent, which is a precursor to the IE GIVE skills.
entry.homework: The homework this week is working on the GIVE skill from Interpersonal Effectiveness, which focused on validation. This basically means listening and trying to understand others. I'm consciously trying to view other's interactions in a more neutral or positive light, and give people the benefit of the doubt more often. If you assume someone is coming from a good place, it changes the way you might interpret their meaning, especially if they're someone who doesn't always do the best job expressing themselves in words.
entry.gratitude: My keyboard, songwriting, the ability to play music and the past training that I have. The fact I grew up so steeped in music that it's easy to reach back out for now.

entry.homework:
I'm hiding from the DEAR MAN script homework, bc I can't breathe when I think about dealing with that level of conflict head on. BUT I did find a Terry Pratchett (also someone who brings me joy) that's going to become my DBT motto, I think:

"There have been times, lately, when I dearly wished that I could change the past. Well, I can’t, but I can change the present, so that when it becomes the past it will turn out to be a past worth having."
-Tiffany Aching, I Shall Wear Midnight

I'm gonna call that a DBT homework victory for the day. I'll look over the worksheet again, though.
entry.gratitude:
Grateful that I got to spend time with my partner today. We went for a walk around Reed College, which has lovely old buildings, and trails through large shady trees, and generally just a quiet, peaceful feel to it. The world in general feels crazy and chaotic right now, and like everything is falling apart all at once (bc of the heatwaves, pandemic, wildfires, etc) but being at Reed with Kent was like a little pocket of peace and fresh air. 

I also started the day by watching the Long Pond Sessions with Taylor Swift, Aaron Dessner, and  Jack Antonoff, and that was honestly so inspiring. I want to start writing music, and getting back into it has been like excavating who I used to be after a long, long winter. So learning more about song writing, and just immersing myself in music (especially music made be people I creatively admire) was a really good thing!

tl;dr I worked hard to create calm, restful and rejuvenating spaces for myself today, but alone and with Kent, and it worked out! There's a LOT I'm grateful for rn.

entry.homework:
This week's homework is to write out a DEAR MAN script for an interpersonal interaction. Here's my attempt to use it for my client meeting tomorrow, with a client who hasn't done their part in the project. 

Prompting event: the project is stalled. Each party has things they need to take responsibility for, and action on, before work can get done again. My objectives are to get both parties to divide work evenly, and to both have buy-in for their part of the work. 

I'm honestly too tired to care about the relationship atm; I just want to get the project done, and I'm willing to be a bit unlikeable to get that to happen. Self respect is important, but again, my primary goal here is just to do whatever I need to do to get the "show on the road" so to speak. 

I do recognize that I need to be relational and personable to be effective in this situation, so I will, but my goal isn't really the relationship itself - that ship has sort of sailed for me.

DEAR MAN script: 

1. Describe situation: "We all care about this project, and we all it to be successful. We all want to get resources to youth, and we all have a personal vested interest and passion in this area. We're coming up on roadblocks, but I think if we can clarify roles, and who's responsible for what, we can move forward successfully together."

2. Express feelings/opinions: "We've spent a lot of time putting together these resources for gathering data, and we think they should give you a solid start and foundation. I'd like to go over the material today, and answer any questions you can think of, and we'll be available for ongoing questions as well by Slack or email." 

3. Assert request directly: "We can only build the application when we have a good amount (how much?) of data to work with. That may take (X) hours, and (describe data gathering process here.) I'd like to talk about the resources and schedule you're planning to dedicate, so we can figure out on our end what our work schedule will be."

4. Reinforce: "We're also excited and eager to see this project come to fruition, and we've built a solid house for the data to live in. As soon as we can get the data we need, we can build out the rest of the application, then do beta testing, then get this out to the people who need it!" 

5. Mindful - Just keep referring back to the goal of getting the project done, and getting resources into the hands of youth. 

6. Negotiating - If/when issues come up, make it a values based instead of position based, and ask them for solutions. Turn the table if needed. 

"We didn't plan to be the data experts on this; we agreed and expected to provide guidance on data shape. If more help is still needed, what do you suggest we should do?" 

7. Validating - ask for their struggles, listen and reflect back. Validate their need to get this done. 

8. Easy manner - maintain spirit of camaraderie.

entry.homework:
DEAR MAN Homework for DBT Providence group today:

Situation: SR being late all the time and spotty and inconsistent with communication

Prompting event for my problem: Who did what to whom? What led up to what? 
Street Roots has consistently cancelled meetings with little or no notice, and has blocked out communication for months at a time. Last year, we went a full 6 months without being able to talk to them in person, all while we were under a strict deadline so that the site didn’t break.

As a result, we had to make decisions on our own, and dedicate our own time to making sure the site didn’t break. It was very frustrating and felt very unfair. It’s also hard to work in such a way.

Objectives in Situation (What results I want): 
Street Roots to show up on time, and communicate in a timely manner. Also, an agreement that whatever we agree on in the meetings actually happens. We can’t help fix what we don’t know about. 

Relationship Issue (How I want the other person to feel about me): 
I want the relationship to be a strong, mutually respectful working relationship. I want us to be able to communicate clearly and efficiently. I want us to like each other and work well together.

Self-Respect Issue (How I want to feel about myself):
I refuse to work with someone who treats me like this, frankly. For my self respect, the other person either needs to change their behavior, or I need to set a boundary about working with them. (Maybe I should talk to Andrew?) 

Describe situation: There is a communication breakdown right now between our two organizations. Last year, many times we were asked for urgent requests, and then ignored when we fulfilled them. We also had to wait 6 months to get any face time with Sophie and Kaia, despite repeatedly asking, and repeatedly scheduling meetings.

Those meetings were usually scheduled a month out, because we were told there was no sooner time available, but when the time for the meeting came, it was usually cancelled with less than 24 hours notice, and no explanation or apology. 

This happened twice in a row, and both were instances we had critical questions that remained unanswered. Our work was much less efficient because of it.

When we did finally connect with Kaia and Sophie, in December 2020, we learned things that would have greatly benefitted us to know 6 months earlier than that. Again, the project suffered. 

Additionally, we have been asked for urgent work on short notice, and complied because we felt it was the moral thing to do (specific wildfire example), only to have all communication from Street Roots cease for weeks. By the time our emails were responded to, the 40+ hours of emergency work we had put in were no longer relevant or needed, meaning that all that (free, urgent weekend) labor had gone to waste. 

Express feelings: It’s very frustrating, as a professional, to be treated this way. We’re doing this primarily for free - even the grants we get cover at best half of the hours we work, and usually more like a third. So we’re volunteering the majority of our time.

I’m happy to volunteer that time - I do it because I care. However, I’d like to be treated with basic rules of respect. I need clear and timely communication, and I need as much notice as possible if a meeting needs to be cancelled. 

Assert: Also, I would like to agree that if someone cancels a set meeting, it’s their responsibility to find a time to reschedule with everyone, and set and host that meeting. 

Reinforce: Getting on the same page about how we communicate will be good for the project and for the community it benefits. It will also help all of us work as effectively as possible, and it will help us save a LOT of development time, which makes it possible to create more features for the same amount of money.

entry.notes:
10 AM

I'm feeling tired but also happy and relaxed bc I started the day by playing piano. That's a good way to start the day, and it makes my ratings for gratitude, calm, and joy all v high. 

Racing thoughts 2/5: What I have atm is more like "racing emotions" honestly; I'm trying to work through ways I feel about HT. And my emotions feel chaotic and all over the place. 

Skills score is 3/5 since I'm working on homework for group - DEAR MAN skills. I don't often sit down and be this intentional about skills practice, so it's good that I am!

11 AM

It's been a rough week - been sick, having trouble breathing from the smoke. There was also a heat wave, so between that and me possibly being contagious, I've been stuck inside and the days are all kind of running together. Feeling depressed, I think. Low energy, lots of fatigue. 

My brain just feels tired and dead today; hard to breathe, and I'm definitely suffering mentally from being cooped up for so long.

On the plus side, I wrote a song! So I'm keeping my chin up the best that I can
